Discoveries, inventions and industrial revolutions: On the varying contribution of technologies and institutions from an international historical perspective. Hist. Technol., 1996, 18: 39-58. "This presentation ranges rather widely, from the condi- tions of discovery in 18th-century Britain to the character of industrialization in modem East Asia. Pp. 49-71 in Marco Beretta (et al., eds.) Per una storia critica della scienza. Bologna: Cisalpino, 1996. 1336 Bonelli, Federico; Russo, Lucio. The origin of modem astronomical theories of tides: Chrisogono, de Dominis and their sources. Brit. J. Hist. Sci., 1996, 29: 385- 401. "In this paper we suggest that a close examination of certain 16th- and 17th-century works on the nature of tides (particularly the works of Federico Chrisogono, Marco Antonio de Dominis and John Wallis) leads to two conclusions. First, the widespread opinion which holds the theory of gravitation developed by Newton as the sole source of scientific basis for the study of tides must be abandoned; on the contrary, the astronomical theories of tides established in the 16th and 17th centuries comprised just one of the elements which allowed Newton to achieve his synthesis. Second, these theories were not based on new observations but were themselves attempts to recover knowledge from Hellenistic science." 1337 Brahe, Tycho. Instruments of the re- newed astronomy. "In this paper I shall consider some of the ways in which Vesalius adapted and modified Galen's ideas about pur- posive design in the human body. My objective is not to trace stages in teleological thinking in the history of anatomy. 'The society of Jesus established an extensive range of measures designed to ensure uniformity in natural philo- sophical questions. These culminated in the Ordinatio pro Studiis Superioribus of 1651. 'Those books that shaped polite science in the first half of the century were primarily English translations of Continental works-Bernard Fontenelle's Conversations on the plurality of worlds (first published in English in 1687, but republished in a new translation in 1715), Noel Antoine Pluche's multi-volume Nature display'd (the first volume of which appeared in English in 1733), Voltaire's Elements of Sir Isaac Newton's philosophy (published in English in 1738) and Francesco Algarotti's Philosophy of Sir Issac Newton explained (of which the English translation appeared in 1739); a relatively small English literature complemented these works, of which John Harris's Astronomical dialogues (1719) was the most important." 2002 Zbinden, Jiirg. "Leonhard Euler treated in his study 'De motu vibratorio tympanorum,' published in 1766, the theory of the vi- brating rectangular and circular membrane mathematically in such a comprehensive way that little more had to be added, considering today's standards. Discipline identifi- cation in chemistry and physics. Sci. Context, 1996, 9: 93-119. "This paper is about discipline identification and bound- aries and what we can leam from exploring them in their historical and linguistic context. The aim has been to ex- amine and compare, side by side, the emerging languages of discourse of physics and chemistry, yet rather more from the perspective of chemistry as it relates to physics than the other way around. The inquiry, with supporting examples, draws mostly on the nineteenth century because that was the time during which the disciplines of chem- istry and physics became conscious, in a critical way, of each other's activities, working agendas, languages, and self-image elaborations." 2513 Holmberg, Gustav. "Edward Tylor's animist theory, and his theory of the survival of the soul were the basis for a large anthro- pological movement which grouped together a number of disciplines involved in the reconstruction of human prehis- toric religion, as well as the identification of the savage components of civilized religions. From 1884 onwards, this British movement spread to France through a number of authors who are not very well known today. Their writings are nevertheless useful for their characterisation of religious studies of Tylorian inspiration." From the English summary. 2806 Russon, John. "Rather than medical superintendents being central to the admission of patients, this paper will argue that control over confinement was predicated upon the desires of families to care for and control dependent and violent relatives. The confinement of the insane can thus be seen not as a consequence of a professionalizing psychiatric elite, but rather as a strategic response of households to the stresses of industrialization." 38h. "In this paper I shall argue that Fraunhofer's work on the dark lines of the spectrum was neither the culmination of any theoretical outlook on the nature of light nor an early effort in spectroscopy. "Both the Superconducting Super Collider and the Human Genome Project originated as ideas in the early 1980s and by the latter part of the decade initiatives had been taken to establish each as a large-scale project of the U.S. federal government. The eighth day of creation: Makers of the revolution in biology. Expanded edition. xxii + 714 pp., illus., notes, index. Plainview, N.Y.: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, 1996. 3454 Junker, Thomas. Kulturpessimismus und Genetik: Von Weimar zum Dritten Reich. Biol. Zentralbl., 1996, 115(2-3): 145-152. 3455 Kay, Lily E. Cybernetics, information, life: The emergence of scriptural represen- tations of heredity. Configurations, 1997, 5: 23-91. "How did molecular biologists come to view organisms and molecules as information storage and retrieval systems, and heredity as information transfer? By which historical microprocess did the genome come to be conceptualized as a coded text written in a natural language? In this paper I examine the production of the information discourse: the emergence, from the 1940s to the mid-1950s, of this new field of representation; its scope; and its limits. I follow the rise of cybernetics by focusing primarily on Norbert Wiener; the mathematical theory of communication and Claude Shannon; computing and automata studies as articulated by John von Neumann; and Henry Quastler's attempts to recast biology (and heredity) as an information science." 3456 Kay, Lily E. Rethinking institutions: Philanthropy as an historiographic problem of knowledge and power. Minerva, 1997, 35: 283-293. The politics of scientific social reform, 1936-1960: Goodwin Watson and the Society for the Psychological Study of Social Issues. J. Hist. Behav. Sci., 1997, 33: 39-60. "This paper explores the development and subsequent transformation of a 'radical' professional model in Amer- ican psychology. Its focal point is Goodwin Watson and the Society for the Psychological Study of Social Issues, an organization Watson helped found in 1936. During the Depression, he and many of his SPSSI colleagues called upon psychologists to abandon value neutrality and polit- ical disinterestedness in favor of an explicit set of social democratic goals and left-wing political alliances." 3610 O'Hara, Phillip Anthony. "I first briefly describe how the modem western under- standing of the etiology and treatment of tuberculosis was conveyed to China directly, by Protestant missionaries, and indirectly, via Japan. I then argue that the germ theory was perceived differently in different sections of Chinese society, and that these differences were further amplified in the process of selective assimilation by which vari- ous groups reinterpreted western medical knowledge in context-specific ways." 3663 Angell, Marcia. "Appendicitis and its operative treatment serve as a win- dow on the emergence of surgical therapy as the twentieth century began. In 1890 only a few practitioners saw ap- pendicitis as an exclusively surgical disease to be managed by an experienced surgeon, with an appropriate operation as the most likely therapy. In 1920 their position was dominant, both within the American medical profession and among the general public, and the experience with ap- pendicitis would be used in other debates to both explain and campaign for the validity of surgical judgement and the wider understanding of surgical disease." 3861 Sogner, Knut. North American urban mass transit, 1890-1950: What if we thought about it as a type of technology? Hist. and Technol., 1995, 12: 309-326. "Arguing that historical literature on North American urban transit has neglected its social shaping, this essay views the network from the vantage point labelled the 'consumption junction' by R.S. Cowan; that is through the eyes of riders. The essay discusses five consumer concerns that influenced their willingness to use public transit: air quality (the smoking issue); vehicle noise; speed of the journey; novelty (the equipment's modernity and status appeal); and security from sexual harassement."
